title: How to Choose a Crochet Project

parts.name: Deciding the Type of Project to Try

steps.headline: Consider your level of skill.
steps.description: Make sure you can perform the basic crochet stitches, such as single or double crochet. Patterns will normally tell you what skill level you have to be to accomplish them. Choose something you already have some experience in (i.e. if you already know all the stitches or if you have made one before). Coasters are generally easy and quick projects, which makes them perfect for beginners. Scarves and hats are also a good idea, although they take a bit longer. For intermediate/advanced levels, more difficult projects like mittens and socks are a good challenge, as well as amigurumi (a type of knitted or crocheted stuffed toy).

steps.headline: Consider what item you need the most, or what might be needed by another.
steps.description: For instance, do not make a scarf if you have already have several. Make something you do not have or haven't yet tried. If you have a specific person in mind, for instance, a pregnant woman, then it might be good to make a set. Choose three or four patterns that match your skill level. For a baby, you could make booties, a blanket, and a headband. Wrap them in a cute basket and you have a perfect gift for a baby shower!

steps.headline: Consider the yarn you currently have on hand.
steps.description: If you only have a little amount of yarn, going for a blanket would be impractical as you wouldn't have enough yarn to finish it. Most projects will tell you the amount of yarn required, so be sure to check this before diving into a project.

steps.headline: Search the Internet.
steps.description: Like with most types of research, the Internet is your best friend! Type "crochet," put in the type of project you want to try (such as scarves, beanies, etc.) and add "patterns." This should bring up what you are looking for right away. For example, if you are looking for patterns on coasters, you should type "crochet coaster patterns." Unless you want to pay money, it is best to add "free" before the "patterns" part to prevent results that require you to buy the pattern.

steps.headline: Browse through sites that offer free crochet patterns.
steps.description: Some of the most well known are The Spruce Crafts and AllFreeCrochet. This may make it quicker for you to find the project you want instead of searching through the Internet.

steps.headline: Search YouTube.
steps.description: Especially if you are a beginner, learning how to do a project through a video can be easier than learning through an article. Plus, all YouTube videos are free to watch, so you don't need to worry about coming upon a cute pattern only to discover that you have to buy it.

steps.headline: Look through books/magazines at the library.
steps.description: Many of the manuals at the library that teach crocheting will also include some free patterns along with them. While they may not have exactly what you are looking for, this is a great idea if you don't know exactly what type of project you want to try.

steps.headline: Keep track of the patterns you find.
steps.description: If you see a good one that you would like to attempt, but that looks too hard for you right now, take note of where you found it so that you can get back to it when your crocheting knowledge has improved. This is also a good idea if you don't currently have the supplies the pattern asks for, or don't have the time to attempt it at present.
